Bulger plans to take stand at trial

James "Whitey" Bulger, once America’s most wanted criminal, will try to convince a jury that federal officials once granted him immunity for his many crimes, his lawyer said during a hearing Monday. (Globe)

Sikhs feel misunderstood and at risk since 9/11

Sikhism, the major religion with about 25 million adherents worldwide at the center of the Wisconsin shooting, remains little known in the United States.
Opinion | Dan Shaughnessy

Red Sox backing Bobby Valentine?

Owner John Henry issued an ultra-defensive vote of confidence for his beleaguered manager, but it doesn’t look like the Red Sox are letting Bobby be Bobby.
Opinion | Farah Stockman

Tea Party sees UN plot to control US

Every international agreement is seen as a threat to US sovereignty in the eyes of some Tea Party activists.

Fed must do more, Boston chief says

Eric Rosengren, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, is urging the nation’s central bankers to ignore election-year pressures and jump-start the economy.

Site aids charities through Amazon

Dan Sipple, 19, launched Buy For Us, a program that gives about 5 percent of a customer’s purchase price on Amazon.com to a charity.
Frame by Frame | Sebastian Smee

Horror and beauty, indivisible

Painted by Hyman Bloom, one of the most compelling artists to emerge from Boston in the 20th century, “Hull” shows a human body with its viscera exposed.

Mission to Mars began in Cambridge

MIT graduate Allen Chen has devoted the last decade of his life to NASA’s Curiosity project, which successfully landed a rover on Mars Sunday.

Heavy rains paralyze Philippine capital, kill 8

Torrential rains in the Philippine capital triggered a landslide that killed eight people and sent government emergency crews scrambling Tuesday to rescue and evacuate thousands.
